newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Emperor Mines annual profit falls sharply.
newsitem.headline: Emperor Mines annual profit falls sharply.

text.p: Fijian-based gold miner Emperor Mines Ltd said on Monday that its 1996/97 (June-July) net profit slumped to A$1.07 million from A$9.53 million a year ago.
The company said its unaudited fourth quarter net profit of A$1.17 million after abnormal items included a A$9.44 million profit from hedging.
"The past 12 months have been challenging for the mine, with production below expectation resulting in higher unit cash costs," it said in its fourth quarter report.

The Vatukuola mine faced sharply lower average head grades in the quarter at 5.69 grams per tonne of gold from 7.30 g/t in the third quarter, with production falling to 32,580 ounces from 29,985 ounces in the third quarter.
Emperor said in February that it expected fourth quarter production to reach at least 40,000 ounces but said earlier this month that it was not likely to reach its 140,000 output target for 1996/97.

The company did not issue annual production figures but the 1996/97 result was estimated to be 124,662 ounces based on the 92,082 ounces produced in the first nine months, according to the third quarter report.
Emperor said its cash cost per ounce jumped to A$595 in the latest quarter from A$495 in the third quarter. The realised price received rose to A$741 per ounce from A$565.
